entries.meaning: (informal) Capable of being finely or idly adjusted with the fingers.
examples: Through the open doorway Nedda could see  […]  the back of Mr. Cuthcott in a twiddly chair, surrounded by sheets of paper reposing on the floor, shining like autumn leaves on a pool of water.

The design of an indicator is often — indeed usually — thought to be the business of the engineer, perhaps aided by someone — an artist or a "stylist" — who adds an aesthetic touch, a twiddly bit, a strip of chromium, a dash of paint, or better still several dashes in clashing colours, of which a bilious yellow will be one.

entries.meaning: (informal) In music, having a rapid series of musical notes.
examples: The bugle called, a twiddly bit and then one long note.
